title.value: Local field potentials in human motor and non-motor brain areas encode the direction of upcoming movements: An intracerebral EEG classification study
title.justification: This title accurately reflects the topic and scope of the paper, which investigates the encoding of movement direction in human brain areas using intracerebral EEG and machine learning.
title.quote: Local field potentials in human motor and non-motor brain areas encode the direction of upcoming movements: An intracerebral EEG classification study

extractions.description: This paper investigates how local field potentials in human motor and non-motor brain areas encode the direction of upcoming movements. It uses intracerebral EEG data and a machine learning framework to analyze features such as oscillatory phase, amplitude, and phase-amplitude coupling during motor planning and execution.

type.justification: The study involves data collection through intracranial EEG recordings from participants and analyzes this data using machine learning to draw empirical conclusions.
type.quote: Here, we set out to probe the directional-tuning of oscillatory phase, amplitude and Phase-Amplitude Coupling (PAC) during motor planning and execution, using a machine learning framework on multi-site local field potentials (LFPs) in humans.

name.justification: The paper primarily investigates brain activity related to motor functions and movements, fitting well within the domain of neuroscience.
name.quote: Our findings show that the direction of upcoming movements can be predicted using spectral features extracted during movement planning from widely distributed human LFPs.

name.justification: The study's findings have direct implications for brain-machine interface technology, particularly in decoding human motor intentions for applications like prosthetics.
name.quote: The ability to infer movement type and direction from invasive and non-invasive recordings has a direct clinical application for brain-computer interfaces (Rezeika et al., 2018; Caldwell et al., 2022; Tang et al., 2023).

name.justification: The study focuses extensively on understanding how different brain regions and oscillatory features contribute to motor planning and execution, making motor control a significant sub-field.
name.quote: Our results provide evidence for successful prediction (up to 86%) of intended arm movements in humans, using combinations of oscillatory phase and power features extracted from LFPs in motor and non-motor structures.

name.justification: LDA was one of the classification algorithms used in the study to decode movement directions from the EEG data.
name.quote: The performance of several classification algorithms (Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), Naïve Bayes (NB), k-th Nearest Neighbor (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM) with linear and Radial Basis Function (RBF) kernels) were compared. They all provided similar performances, and we finally chose the LDA for its efficiency.

is_contributed.justification: LDA is a well-established machine learning algorithm and wasn't specifically developed in this study.
is_contributed.quote: We finally chose the LDA for its efficiency.

is_executed.justification: The LDA model was executed as part of the machine learning framework applied to the EEG data.
is_executed.quote: The performance of the classifier was evaluated by computing the % decoding accuracy (i.e. proportion of successfully classified samples in the test set), which was obtained following a standard stratified 10 times 10-fold cross-validation scheme.

is_compared.justification: The LDA model's performance was compared numerically with other models like Naïve Bayes, k-th Nearest Neighbor, and Support Vector Machine.
is_compared.quote: They all provided similar performances, and we finally chose the LDA for its efficiency.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The use of LDA wasn't specifically referenced to any paper in the study.

name.justification: EEGLAB was used for data preprocessing, specifically implementing the FIR Least-Squares filter for extracting phase and amplitude components from the EEG data.
name.quote: We first filtered the data in the required band using a two-way zero-phase lag finite impulse response (FIR) Least-Squares filter implemented in the EEGLAB toolbox (Delorme and Makeig, 2004).

referenced_paper_title.value: EEGLAB: an open source toolbox for analysis of single-trial EEG dynamics including independent component analysis
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper specifies the original publication for EEGLAB in its reference section.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Delorme A, Makeig S (2004) EEGLAB: an open source toolbox for analysis of single-trial EEG dynamics including independent component analysis. J Neurosci Methods 134:9–21.

name.justification: scikit-learn was used for implementing various machine learning classification algorithms, including LDA, Naïve Bayes, KNN, and SVM.
name.quote: All classifications were implemented in Python 3 using the scikit-learn package (Pedregosa et al., 2011).
